nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) is pseudoscience because it has produced few falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
EE prescribes growth rate optimization: maximize long-run geometric average (time-average growth rate) of wealth

Method: Two-asset continuous-time model with risky asset following geometric Brownian motion and continuously rebalanced fixed portfolio fraction theta; wealth dynamics derived by Ito leading to lognormal terminal wealth
Result (EE): Maximizing long-run geometric growth yields optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r) / sigma squared
Result (EUT): Expected utility maximization with CRRA utility yields optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma squared)
Claim: EE and EUT give identical prediction for the two-asset problem when relative risk aversion gamma equals one (log utility)
Claim: EE currently lacks broader testable implications beyond special cases and therefore is not demonstrably falsifiable

Evidence: While the two-asset problem yields a testable theta formula, EE has not provided solutions or testable prescriptions for multi-period consumption-investment problems (e.g., 3-period or longer horizons)

Claim: EE meets several Wikipedia-listed indicators of pseudoscience: vague or untestable claims, improper evidence, lack of openness to expert testing, absence of progress, personalization, and misleading language

Evidence: Specific examples supporting pseudoscience indicators include grandiose claims resolving decision theory without concrete applications, mis-citations, reliance on very old works, and unclear use of terms like equilibrium and ergodicity
Evidence: The only experimental citation cited by Peters is Meder et al., which has been criticized, and Peters cites other works out of context
Conclusion: Given the lack of broad testable implications and multiple indicators of pseudoscience, EE should be treated skeptically and avoided until it produces falsifiable results
Limitation: The author is not an expert in EE and focuses critique primarily on Peters 2019 Nature Physics paper as representative
Context: Popperian falsifiability criterion and Wikipedia indicators of pseudoscience are used as normative standards for evaluating EE
Claim: Mainstream economic theory (e.g., expected utility frameworks) yields testable, falsifiable implications by formulating consumption-portfolio problems and deriving quantitative predictions
Method/Result: Analytical derivations use Ito's lemma and properties of the lognormal distribution and moment generating functions to obtain EE and EUT objective functions and optimal theta formulas
